newsitem.title: INDIA: India sugar firm after govt hikes prices to public.
newsitem.headline: India sugar firm after govt hikes prices to public.

text.p: Indian sugar prices firmed on the local market on Tuesday following a government decision to raise selling prices to the public, dealers said.
"Higher consumer demand as well as speculative buying on the back of hike in the sugar prices supplied through the public distribution system dragged prices upward in the open market," dealers said.
The Indian government on Monday hiked selling prices of sugar supplied through public distribution system from 9.05 rupees per kg to 10.50 rupees per kg.

Ready delivery sugar S-30 rose by 10/20 rupees to 1,270/1,300 rupees per quintal while M-30 moved up by 10/15 rupees to 1,315/1,390 rupees per quintal. Sugar mill delivery was up by 15 rupees at 1,215/1,230 rupees per quintal.
The price of sugar supplied through public distribution system was 6.90 rupees per kg in 1992, 8.30 rupees per kg in 1993, and 9.05 rupees per kg in 1994.
"Since 1994 government had not revised prices and burden of the subsidy on government was heavy," said Shantilal Dedhiya, secretary to Bombay Sugar Merchant Association.
"The hike was overdue and came at last," he said.
Indians consume about 400,000 tonnes of sugar supplied through public distribution system per month.
